report_title: Industry Report: Human Resources & Benefits Administration
executive_summary: Human resources and benefits administration providers have recently benefited from growing corporate profit, higher employment and rising consumer spending, encouraging companies to outsource administrative duties. Earlier in the period, the emergence of COVID-19 in 2020 caused high unemployment, limiting demand for the industry's services. Despite pandemic-related declines, revenue flourished in 2021 and 2022 as companies recovered from the economic downturn. Revenue growth has slowed recently because of high-interest rates and falling per capita disposable income.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 and the Pandemic Recovery Induced Volatility
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As the pandemic and related shutdowns impacted the economy, many businesses were forced to permanently close their storefronts, limiting the pool of clients. Other businesses and organizations cut off the industry's services, hoping to lower overhead costs while weathering the downturn. Pandemic aid and legislation, such as the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), Economic Injury Disaster Loans (EIDL) and enhanced unemployment benefit programs made administering employee benefits more complex, increasing demand for the industry's services. As a result, revenue declined only slightly in 2020.

Human resources and benefits administrators have been increasingly adopting new software to automate administrative tasks such as payroll, attendance tracking, onboarding and benefits enrollment. The industry has also built web-based platforms that enable employees to request time off, access pay stubs, update personal details and engage in other functions. One company that specializes in these functions is Automatic Data Processing, Inc. (ADP). Artificial intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) systems have also been added to identify talent, predict employee turnover, screen job applicants and personalize benefits packages to suit an employee's needs. Adopting these technologies has made human resources and benefits administration more efficient and attractive, attracting customers and aiding revenue growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COMPANIES HAVE BEEN INCREASINGLY OUTSOURCING THEIR HR SERVICES
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Businesses more heavily view outsourcing as an adequate means to manage non-core administrative duties while the company concentrates on core missions. Businesses have also sought help with increasingly complex compliance and regulation. Duties such as payroll processing, human resources, customer service and even IT maintenance can be effectively outsourced, freeing up valuable internal resources for core business functions. Large and mid-sized businesses have especially had the incentive to outsource HR services since they have the funds to do so. This has given them a competitive advantage over smaller players in their industries since big companies can hone their resources and time into primary functions. Increased outsourcing has raised demand for human resources and benefits administrators, helping revenue expand during the current period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE HIGH COST OF BORROWING HAS CAUSED REVENUE TO SLOW
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Record-high inflation has groped the US economy as supply chain disruptions, loose monetary policy and massive government spending caused prices to soar. The Federal Reserve has raised interest rates to tame rising prices. The high cost of borrowing has made it more difficult for businesses to invest in land, buildings and other forms of equipment. Since capital investment is essential for the functioning of many corporations, some businesses have scaled back human resources programs to ensure they can afford to pay higher interest rates on equipment. Many companies have reduced their investment in third-party human resources and benefits administration service providers or started producing essential services entirely in-house. This has caused revenue growth to slow recently. Per capita disposable income has also declined as government subsidies have stopped, hindering demand from households and contributing to the slowdown in revenue growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: STEADY ECONOMIC CONDITIONS WILL BOOST DEMAND FROM Small Businesses
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite challenges related to high inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears, GDP will rise steadily during the outlook period. Solid economic conditions will increase employment, corporate profit, the number of businesses and access to credit. Smaller companies view the industry as a luxury – they will only contract with human resources and benefits administrations when business is stable. Since corporate profit will rise during the outlook period, small businesses will have the funds to outsource human resources and benefits administration to the industry, aiding revenue growth. As economic growth causes the number of businesses to expand, providers will be swarmed by a wave of new clients looking to expand. In particular, the number of temporary employees is set to swell, creating constant demand for training services and benefits administration – two of the industry's largest segments.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Increased Demand From Large Businesses Will Keep Major Players Relevant
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Large businesses often prefer a blanket solution, outsourcing numerous tasks to a single firm that can handle their work. This includes wide-reaching administrative tasks such as paperwork, documentation and legal issues. Delegating these responsibilities helps big corporations focus on their core business activities. Providers in this market often need to offer supplementary services, including tax preparation, accounting and payroll and bookkeeping services. Many smaller administrators don't have the resources to handle these issues, creating a disparity between players. High corporate profit will keep demand from large businesses elevated. Since major human resources and benefits administration service providers have the resources to service big corporations, they'll remain relevant as spending from large businesses remains high.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Costs to Compete Will Grow
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Clients will continue to favor providers that integrate software and new technology into their solutions. Human resources and benefits administrators may be forced to invest in new technology or lose clients. Despite the importance of adopting new systems, many smaller companies will view software services as a luxury instead of a necessity since it's difficult to afford software upgrades, new computers and better services. While the increased importance of new software and technology will benefit larger players, concentration will still decline during the outlook period. Growth in the number of businesses, higher corporate profit and soaring employment will increase the number of revenue streams, encouraging entry into the industry and causing establishments and enterprises to rise at a much faster pace than revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Industry Will Face Threats From In-House HR Service Providers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The continued expansion of effective in-house HR departments will threaten HR and benefits administrators. With the help of HR software, internal HR teams are improving, reducing the need for the industry's services. Large HR service providers will respond to this threat by investing in cloud-based HR software solutions. Cloud-based software can be accessed anywhere with an internet connection. Since cloud-based solutions are more convenient, they save businesses time and resources, making them more cost-competitive. This feature is particularly attractive to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Despite these investments, companies can expect increased pressure on revenues as homemade HR software gains traction. Specifically, private sector customers will likely address HR-related issues using software.

industry_definition: This industry provides clients with various day-to-day office administrative services, such as assistance with financial planning, billing and record keeping, personnel, physical distribution and logistics. Companies also furnish general and specialized management services on a day-to-day basis and a contracted or fee-for-service basis.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: Outsourcing has steadily increased, particularly as business growth hastens following the pandemic. More outsourcing has raised demand for the services human resources and benefits administrators offer, causing revenue to expand.
Rising corporate profit will enable greater spending from small businesses, boosting revenue. However, heightened competition from substitutes such as in-house services will limit growth.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Mid-sized and large businesses are the industry's most extensive client base. These companies often have greater reasons to outsource human resources and benefits administration, as a greater number of workers require more extensive human resources departments with complicated benefits management.

Smaller companies don't have the capital to hire in-house administrative services, so they often purchase the industry's services. Their market share isn't as high as mid-sized and large companies since some small businesses don't have the funds to pay third parties.

Mid-sized and large businesses are the industry's most extensive client base. These companies often have greater reasons to outsource human resources and benefits administration, as a greater number of workers require more extensive human resources departments with complicated benefits management.

Growing compliance and case management duties have led more individuals to outsource their work to third parties. Products related to 401(k) savings plans are especially popular among self-employed individuals.

Nonprofit organizations outsource human resource management to the industry to more effectively focus on their own line of work. Since nonprofits rely on donations from corporations and individuals, solid economic conditions benefit this sector.
Government agencies often outsource human resources and benefits administration to improve bureaucratic efficiency and cut down on administrative expenses.

products_and_services.product_description: This type of administration involves handling sensitive and complicated employment issues, including ongoing supervisory education and training regarding risk management.

Benefit programs normally include life insurance coverage, pension plans and a choice of different health, dental, vision and prescription card coverages. Companies don't directly underwrite insurance plans but provide prepackaged plans to clients on behalf of insurance companies.
Human resources and benefits administrators offering regulatory-compliance management often assume responsibility for companies' compliance with many employment-related regulatory requirements.
Other services primarily include succession and leadership planning services.

tier_1_suppliers: Internet Service Providers in the US
Wired Telecommunications Carriers in the US
Credit Card Issuing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Data Processing & Hosting Services in the US
tier_1_buyers: Professional, Scientific and Technical Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Human Resources Administration Spikes Following the Pandemic
demand_determinants.determinant_description: A spike in unemployment in 2020 followed by massive rehiring in 2021 and 2022 contributed to swelling demand for human resources services, causing their revenue share to surge during the current period.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: HIGH PLAN COMPLEXITY MAKES BENEFITS ADMINISTRATION NECESSARY
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Expanded plan participation and higher complexity resulting from more stringent regulatory and legislative compliance requirements have led to increased demand for benefits administration, causing benefits administration's revenue share to rise during the current period.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: REGULATORY COMPLIANCE PROVIDERS HAVE BEEN AIDED BY NEW REGULATIONS
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The continuous introduction of new legislation, particularly within the finance and insurance sector, has driven demand for third-party service providers that offer regulatory compliance management services. This has increased compliance's revenue share during the current period.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region holds a higher proportion of low-wage jobs, particularly in the retail and service sectors. These positions are less likely to have significant benefits and extensive training, limiting demand for the industry's services.
The high number of technology-based jobs in the West, particularly in Silicon Valley, has precipitated high revenue per establishment for administrators in the state.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Stay-at-home guidelines forced providers to shift operations online entirely. Despite this, social distancing measures didn't directly affect the industry's core operations outside of this. Many providers took advantage of these changing regulations by slashing travel costs and conducting all business online. These measures have been relaxed in 2023 as increased immunity reduced the severity of the virus.

The industry is subject to a host of labor laws. The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) was passed in 1938 and imposes labor regulations on all US industries. Human resources and benefits administrators must adhere to minimum wage laws, overtime pay rules and child labor protections under this law. The Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) ensures employees are entitled to unpaid leave in case of a health crisis or the birth of a child.

Since this industry administers employee benefits, they're subject to federal laws relating to them. The Affordable Care Act (ACA) introduced a set of essential health benefits that all employers must offer, so administrators must review plans to ensure their client's health benefits adhere to ACA guidelines. Players must also follow the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), which mandates that employers disclose their health, retirement and other plans honestly and comprehensively.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Industry fragmentation and small business nature
barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is still highly fragmented and most providers are small-scale businesses requiring a massive specialized workforce. The nature of the industry is also service-based, so hiring workers is a much higher barrier to entry than purchasing equipment.
While certifications help administrators differentiate themselves, there aren't any specific licensing requirements, reducing barriers to entry.

factors_decreased_barrier: The industry is service-based, so hiring workers is a much higher barrier to entry than purchasing equipment.
No investment in plants or equipment is necessary.

basis_points.basis_description: Reputation is key to success in the industry. Businesses, households, government agencies and other buyers seek administrators with easy access to downstream markets.
Cloud-based HR services have grown in popularity. While these services enable companies to handle HR and benefits internally, they're often limited in scope and more expensive.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Nonemployers comprise the lion's share of HR businesses, yet they generate just a fraction of total revenue.
The HR field continues attracting smaller startups, with the market growing, low capital requirements and relatively high profit.
Though smaller HR operations rake in less revenue, they are an attractive option for small- or medium-sized businesses seeking to downsize or reduce internal costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs in this industry are cyclical, as providers update outdated software and technology every several years. The industry has increasingly relied on computer systems to maintain account information and data on client engagements.

The industry is still highly fragmented and most providers are small-scale businesses requiring a massive specialized workforce. The nature of the industry is also service-based, so hiring workers is a much higher barrier to entry than purchasing equipment.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The industry is adding new patent technologies at a rate in line with the average across all industries
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: This suggests a stable addition of technology. However, the concentration of technologies is high. This creates the potential for innovation outside the focus of industry leaders to gain traction.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served by incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Revenue moves in line with economic conditions
volatility_points.volatility_description: Companies will forgo renewing contracts with outsourced HR providers during poor economic times. The pandemic created a massive system shock, slashing demand from businesses. Smaller businesses, which make up most of the industry's demand, didn't have the capital to weather prolonged closures.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The diversity of buyers boosts stability
volatility_points.volatility_description: Providers benefit from serving businesses of all sizes and across many sectors, which grants players the ability to mitigate downturns in different segments, hindering revenue volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: HUMAN RESOURCES ADMINISTRATION SPIKES FOLLOWING THE PANDEMIC
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This type of administration involves handling sensitive and complicated employment issues, including ongoing supervisory education and training regarding risk management. Many of these services have also shifted to an online format, enabling service providers to cut costs in transportation and offer services at lower, more competitive price points.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: HIGH PLAN COMPLEXITY MAKES BENEFITS ADMINISTRATION NECESSARY
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Benefit programs normally include life insurance coverage, pension plans and a choice of different health, dental, vision and prescription card coverages. Companies don't directly underwrite insurance plans but provide prepackaged plans to clients on behalf of insurance companies.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: REGULATORY COMPLIANCE PROVIDERS HAVE BEEN AIDED BY NEW REGULATIONS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Specifically, providers must be aware of constant tweaks and updates to legislation, making this service indispensable. Human resources and benefits administrators offering regulatory-compliance management often assume responsibility for companies' compliance with many employment-related regulatory requirements.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: OTHER SERVICES MOSTLY FOCUS ON COMPANY ORGANIZATION
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Other services primarily include succession and leadership planning services. Succession planning services involve identifying and developing employees within an organization to fill essential leadership positions when they're vacated.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche service or bundle its services to attract clients?
FAQs.answer: Some companies provide services not relevant to the industry, including tax preparation, accounting, payroll and bookkeeping services in order to streamline the customer experience.

FAQs.question: How do you market your services to potential clients? Is there a heavy reliance on long-term contracts or repeat clients?
FAQs.answer: Benefits administrators typically use referrals from previous clients to drive new business.

FAQs.question: Does your company target a particular market segment, or provide for a broad range of markets?
FAQs.answer: Benefits administrators provide services to businesses of all sizes, across all sectors. This provides administrators with relatively steady demand.

FAQs.question: Has your company implemented practices to lower purchasing costs?
FAQs.answer: Since benefits administrators require office materials in order to provide their services, their ability to minimize purchases is relatively low.

FAQs.question: Does your business use web-based systems for customer bookings or orders?
FAQs.answer: Benefits administrators can use web-based systems for customer bookings as well as for collecting relevant information to provide customer services.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce costs by automating operations?
FAQs.answer: While some benefits administrators have started using software to minimize labor, operators rely heavily on skilled workers.

FAQs.question: Do regulations pertinent to your business vary from state to state?
FAQs.answer: Regulations do not hamper benefits administrators from operating across various states.

FAQs.question: Is your business responsible for safeguarding customer information?
FAQs.answer: Benefits administrators need to safeguard information given to them by clients, as the nature of the information they handle is highly personal.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: There is next to no equipment needed by benefits administrators to provide their services.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for seasonality of cash flow? How has the pandemic's resulting economic environment impacted performance?
FAQs.answer: Since benefits administrators provide their services to all types of businesses, their cash flow is relatively consistent.

FAQs.question: How do you hire and train personnel? How much prior experience is necessary for employees at your company?
FAQs.answer: To stay competitive, service providers must have access to high-quality personnel who are knowledgeable about changes to labor laws, benefits and conditions.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure effective contract management? Do you have any best practices regarding management of these contracts?
FAQs.answer: Third party providers need solid contract management skills to secure a professional, ongoing relationship.

FAQs.question: Are you able to leverage economies of scale? What has your company done recently to expand its size?
FAQs.answer: The high degree of assimilation in services implies that service providers should be able to achieve significant economies of scale.

FAQs.question: Do you find revenue trends to align with changes in the national unemployment rate? Do you track the national unemployment rate?
FAQs.answer: When the national unemployment rate increases, operators tend to perform fewer transactions for clients, and thus revenue growth slows.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor corporate profit across the United States? How have changes in corporate profit affected your revenue?
FAQs.answer: Corporate profit measures profit earned across all industries in the United States, including the Human Resources and Benefits Administration industry. An increase in corporate profit enables US businesses to outsource more work to specialized companies and therefore results in greater industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the number of businesses in the United States? How has the number of businesses affected your company's revenue?
FAQs.answer: An increase in the number of businesses expands the pool of potential clients for human resources and benefits administrators, translating to higher industry revenue.
